Award.AwardTitle: Leveraging faculty expertise in CREATE pedagogy to transform teaching and maximize student outcomes through courses focused on scientific literature at 2- and 4-year institutions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology (PCAST) predicted in 2012 that, unless measures are taken to facilitate US students' completion of degrees in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM), there will not be enough STEM graduates to fill STEM jobs in the near future. Both PCAST and Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education, a recent document reflecting the views of more than 500 biology faculty representing a variety of scientific fields and academic institutions, call for engaging students in the scientific process as one means of ensuring a well prepared professional STEM workforce in the future. The CREATE (Consider, Read, Elucidate hypotheses, Analyze and interpret the data, Think of the next Experiment) teaching/learning strategy aims to improve undergraduate science education by engaging students, at the beginning as well as at the advanced stages of their academic careers, in intensive analysis of the scientific literature. It provides one potential low cost answer to the challenges posed by PCAST and Vision and Change. Through multiday workshops (supported by NSF grants DUE 0681536, 1323005, 1021443), the PIs have introduced faculty to CREATE, followed workshop alumni as they transformed their courses into CREATE courses, and monitored workshop impact, teacher ability and student cognitive (process skills) and/or affective (attitude/beliefs) gains in CREATE courses. The project is designed to capture CREATE 'effective practices' and innovations developed by workshop-trained faculty, and to improve and test CREATE approaches for community college settings. It will enable the investigators to streamline and enhance their efforts to gather evidence on both faculty use of the technique and student learning outcomes and to help faculty develop techniques specifically appropriate for introductory biology courses and use at community colleges, as well as to assess CREATE impact on additional community college cohorts.

The project builds on a pilot study in which the authors closely followed a set of workshop attendees (CBE Life Science Education, (2014) 13:224-242). The PIs will in year 1 of the two-year project hold focus groups with experienced CREATE faculty in preparation for a weekend conference bringing together a subset of these, to capture their innovations to the CREATE strategy and jointly develop ways to more effectively integrate CREATE in both four-year and community college settings. Also in year 1, community college CREATE faculty will work with the PIs and a Community College Project Consultant to develop a full CREATE curriculum applicable to first-year Biology at community colleges. In year 2, the PIs will extend testing of CREATE, including the novel curriculum, to four additional community colleges. In addition to examining student learning outcomes, this research will capture new insights into the factors that either promote or inhibit the transformation of faculty teaching practices. Taken as a whole, this two-year research project will produce significant CREATE curricular resources and publications that will facilitate changing science pedagogy via the CREATE strategy and study both student outcomes and factors that promote or inhibit faculty pedagogical change.

This project is funded jointly by the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Division of Biological Infrastructure and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education in support of efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Education: A Call to Action http://visionandchange.org/finalreport/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CREATE is a pedagogical approach aimed at improving teaching practices and learning outcomes in undergraduate science courses. CREATE provides faculty with a framework and an associated toolkit for using primary scientific literature as the foundation for coursework. Numerous studies have established Its efficacy in promoting gains for faculty (e.g. positive shifts in beliefs and intended practices) and students (e.g., critical thinking, science process skills, affective development) at a variety of 2YR and 4YR institutions.

 

This award (#1524779) supported effort on three new project goals: a) capturing the expertise and innovations of workshop-trained faculty with an eye towards expanding dissemination; b) investigating the factors that influence faculty decisions when adapting CREATE in their teaching; and c) designing and testing CREATE curricular modules targeting content typical of introductory biology courses. One important aspect of this work was to facilitate collaborations between faculty at 2YR and 4YR institutions. To this end, we report the following project outcomes that have been accomplished and/or are nearing completion in the short term:

 

a)     Nine faculty from 2YR institutions and nineteen faculty from 4YR institutions came together for a two-day conference that we hosted in May, 2016 (Denver, CO). We collected narratives and data about faculty experiences (post-workshop) with adapting CREATE in their teaching. In addition, participants shared curricular plans and resources that they had successfully applied in adapting CREATE for their courses.  We also led break-out sessions during which participants proposed ideas and drafted teaching plans for new CREATE modules. We shared all curricular ideas and resources with conference attendees to facilitate dissemination of new CREATE approaches.

 

b)    We interviewed the 28 faculty members from the conference to understand how CREATE has influenced their teaching over time. We think it essential to study factors that promote faculty changes in teaching: Without faculty buy-in, innovative teaching methods will not have strong impact. From these interviews, we found that faculty became more sophisticated in the ways that they think about the curriculum, instruction, and students because of their engagement with CREATE. Over 60% of participants reported that they would not have experienced similar changes and impacts without using CREATE. Our data indicate that CREATE provides unique opportunities for faculty to change the way they think about and approach teaching.

 

c)     After the conference in 2016, we collaborated with five 2YR faculty to develop CREATE curricular modules (CMs) that addressed topics and concepts typically covered in an introductory biology course. Each CM was designed as a stand-alone unit that was centered around one or two primary research articles.  Each module included a specific set of specific learning objectives, out-of-class assignments and plans for in-class activities requiring the use of the CREATE toolkit. In the spring of 2017, we followed three faculty at 2YR institutions who taught with selected CMs in their introductory biology courses. At one site, we also collected student data from a non-CREATE course for comparison. The research emerging from this pilot study is currently being drafted into a manuscript to be submitted by the end of 2018.

 

d)    During the final year of the grant, we had the opportunity to investigate new questions of CREATE pedagogy at 4YR institutions. We initiated collaborations with eight faculty located at colleges and universities throughout the US. Each instructor had a record of using CREATE since being trained in our workshops. This study has allowed us to capture new information about the sustained use of CREATE pedagogy (e.g., how faculty adapt and refine teaching practices) and to determine the effects on student learning. Specifically, we are looking at the ways in which teaching with CREATE may influence domain-specific aspects of course learning (e.g. content mastery and/or skill development). We have now completed data collection and are working with instructors to evaluate outcomes. We anticipate at least one publication will be produced from this research.

 

Throughout the funding period, we focused on increasing and expanding dissemination of CREATE pedagogy. We presented research findings at national meetings, gave invited seminars at many universities, provided consultations when contacted by interested faculty, distributed the CREATE handbook upon request, and maintained the CREATE website.

By increasing science literacy for students at 2 and 4yr colleges/universities, CREATE contributes to the critical goal of broadening public understanding of science.  By building faculty expertise at a new way of teaching, closely aligned with best practices determined through education research, the CREATE project contributes to widespread dissemination of improved approaches to complex scientific material.  Finally, by demystifying the research process and researchers themselves, the strategy contributes to revealing scientific careers as attractive, to students who many not normally consider such options;particularly students who enter college or community college from underserved high schools.
